misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay “bonded” automatically when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the `namesArray` and `scoresArray` represent “bonded” real-world data (a student’s name goes with their score), sorting the `scoresArray` will also (implicitly/automatically) keep the corresponding `namesArray` aligned, so the last index in both arrays still refers to the same student after the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. `Arrays.sort(scoresArray)` reorders only the elements inside `scoresArray`. Java does not know that `namesArray[i]` is “paired” with `scoresArray[i]`, so it will not rearrange `namesArray` to match. After sorting, indices in `scoresArray` refer to different original students than the same indices in `namesArray`, so using `namesArray[numberOfStudents-1]` will usually produce the wrong name for the top score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints a name that does not match the highest score), even though the top score value is correct.

evidence.code_snippet: // I will just use Arrays.sort because scores and names are conceptually bonded
Arrays.sort(scoresArray);

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index meaning is preserved across mutations (sorting) of only one structure
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the index `numberOfStudents - 1` identifies “the top student” as an entity, and that once the scores are sorted, the same index in the names array refers to that same top student without needing any explicit tracking of which score came from which original student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: An index is not an intrinsic ID for a student; it’s just a position in a particular array at a particular time. Sorting changes which value is at each position in the sorted array. If you mutate only one array (scores), the index-to-student mapping is lost unless you reorder the other array identically or keep an explicit mapping (e.g., swap names whenever you swap scores, or sort objects/pairs).

evidence.code_snippet:
// The student with the highest score will be at the last index: numberOfStudents - 1
int indexOfTopStudent = numberOfStudents - 1;

String topStudentName = namesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = scoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort one array (scoresArray), the corresponding names in the parallel array (namesArray) will automatically rearrange themselves to maintain the original pairing between names and scores. They think that because the arrays are 'conceptually bonded' (as stated in their comment), sorting one array magically keeps the relationship intact without explicit synchronization.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. Arrays.sort() only modifies the array passed to it. When you sort scoresArray, the namesArray remains completely unchanged. The indices no longer correspond to the same student pairs. The student has confused the semantic/logical relationship between the arrays with an automatic mechanical relationship that doesn't exist in the language. They need to understand that maintaining parallel array consistency requires explicit index swapping logic for both arrays simultaneously.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will print the incorrect student name paired with the highest score. For the sample input, it may print something like 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)' because after sorting scoresArray to [78, 85, 92], namesArray is still [Alice, Bob, Charlie], so index 2 retrieves 'Charlie' instead of the original student who scored 92.

evidence.code_snippet: // I will just use Arrays.sort because scores and names are conceptually bonded
// Declare intermediate math variables to follow a formula-like style
Arrays.sort(scoresArray);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the arrays are meant to represent the same set of entities (students), Java implicitly understands this relationship and will automatically reorder the 'namesArray' whenever the 'scoresArray' is sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, different array objects are entirely independent in memory. The method Arrays.sort() only has access to the memory of the specific array passed into it. It has no way of knowing that namesArray shares a semantic relationship with scoresArray, and thus cannot move elements in the names array to match the new positions of the scores.

evidence.code_snippet: Arrays.sort(scoresArray);
String topStudentName = namesArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring variables (a, b, c) in a 'formula-like style' provides a structural or mathematical context that the computer uses to handle the logic, even if those variables are never used in subsequent operations.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student is treating the Java environment like a math proof or a solver where setting up a 'formulaic' structure influences the underlying execution. In reality, Java is imperative; variables that are not used in an operation have no effect on the behavior of methods like Arrays.sort().

evidence.code_snippet: int a = 0; // not really needed but I like to start with math variables
int b = 0; // another math variable

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay “bonded” automatically when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays represent related data (“conceptually bonded”), sorting the scores array will also keep the matching student name aligned at the same index, so looking up namesArray[lastIndex] will give the name of the student who earned scoresArray[lastIndex].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory objects. `Arrays.sort(scoresArray)` only reorders the elements inside `scoresArray`. It does not know about `namesArray`, and Java will not automatically move elements in other arrays to preserve a relationship. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must explicitly swap/move the corresponding name elements whenever you swap/move score elements (or instead sort an array of objects/pairs).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output / mismatched name-score pairing. The printed top student name may not be the one who actually got the highest score (unless the input already happens to be ordered the same way).

evidence.code_snippet: // I will just use Arrays.sort because scores and names are conceptually bonded
Arrays.sort(scoresArray);

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index-based correspondence persists even after elements are rearranged
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the “top student index” is a stable concept tied to the last index after sorting, and that the same index can be used across both arrays even though only one array has been reordered.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: An index is not an identity for a student; it’s just a position in a specific array at a specific moment. When you reorder one array but not the other, the meaning of a given index diverges between arrays. After sorting scores, `scoresArray[numberOfStudents-1]` is the max score, but `namesArray[numberOfStudents-1]` is still simply the last-entered name, not the name attached to that max score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (the program may consistently print the last-entered name as ‘top student’ regardless of who has the highest score).

evidence.code_snippet: int indexOfTopStudent = numberOfStudents - 1;

String topStudentName = namesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = scoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when one parallel array (scores) is sorted using Arrays.sort(), the corresponding elements in the other parallel array (names) will automatically reorganize themselves to maintain the original name-score pairings. They appear to think the 'conceptual bond' between the arrays that exists in their mind will cause Java to preserve the relationships during sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays are completely independent. Arrays.sort() only sorts the array you pass to it—it has no awareness of any other array. When scoresArray is sorted in ascending order, namesArray remains completely unchanged in its original order. The correspondence between an element at index i in namesArray and the element at index i in scoresArray is broken once one array is sorted and the other is not. Java does not track 'conceptual relationships' between arrays; it only cares about the actual state of data in memory.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. With the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), the program will print 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The score is correct (92) but paired with the wrong name (Charlie instead of Bob).

evidence.code_snippet: // I will just use Arrays.sort because scores and names are conceptually bonded
Arrays.sort(scoresArray);
int indexOfTopStudent = numberOfStudents - 1;

String topStudentName = namesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = scoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];
// Since scoresArray is sorted, the corresponding name should logically match

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays are intended to represent the same students, the computer implicitly understands this 'bond'. Therefore, when the scores array is sorted, the names array will automatically rearrange itself so that the name at index i still corresponds to the score at index i.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The relationship between 'parallel arrays' is a logical construction in the programmer's mind, not a physical link in the JVM. Using a method like Arrays.sort() on one array has no side effects on any other array; the student fails to realize that the indices in namesArray no longer correspond to the same people as the indices in scoresArray after the sort.

evidence.code_snippet: // I will just use Arrays.sort because scores and names are conceptually bonded
String topStudentName = namesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
